Theresa May will on Friday attempt to pass half of her Brexit deal through parliament amid signs that she is heading for another significant defeat against an expected backdrop of “Brexit day” protests at Westminster.

The prime minister will seek approval for her withdrawal deal in a vote at 2.30pm, with international trade secretary Liam Fox claiming that Britain’s “political structures are at risk” if MPs continued to block Brexit, which was scheduled to have taken effect at 11pm GMT on Friday.

Tom Dalgleish From what I know, preparing a leased plane to return to service is expensive, they are less efficient and with higher maintenance costs
BE11:22am

Let me share some Morgan Stanley to summarise where we are.

BE11:23am

TUI has warned that the 737 MAX grounding will cost it €200m in FY19,
assuming the grounding lasts until July, and up to another €100m if until
September. It has therefore reduced its FY19 EBITA guidance from flat to -17% to
-26% yoy, using its adjusted FY18 base of €1177m. It says the costs cover leasing
additional aircraft, extending expiring leases for 8 aircraft that were supposed to
be replaced by new 737 MAX aircraft, higher fuel costs, other disruption costs,
and the anticipated impact on trading. TUI has 15 MAX aircraft, around 10% of its
fleet, and we discussed the risk of the grounding in our recent upgrade note here.
Leasing a narrow body aircraft can cost $200k per month or $350k for a full wet
lease, but market tightness could see these baselines move up $400-500k per
month. This implies a monthly cost of €5-6m for TUI, which annualised is 10% of
group EBITA. TUI's €200-300m cost therefore looks high, but it is not clear
whether it includes non cash costs or writedowns, and / or any additional trading
weakness in its figures. Given the weak recent GfK data (last two weeks UK
overseas package holidays down 7-10%), investors may worry the revised
guidance includes other profit shortfalls not directly attributed to the MAX
grounding. The downgrade also implies its Markets & Airlines tour operator
could now generate close to zero EBITA this year, although TUI's valuation is
already factoring in minimal value for this division, on our forecasts. This
downgrade will also raise questions over the dividend, which is uncovered on our
FY19 forecasts given the elevated capex. Assuming the M&A division returns to a
more normal albeit depressed 2% EBITA margin next year, then the dividend
remains 1x covered. The other way to think about the downgrade is that if this is
a one-off cost relating to the MAX grounding, then it is 5% off group’s equity
value, and the shares price is -10% at the time of writing.

Chuck Norris @Electric Dragon love BBR
11:23 am
BE11:24am

And Citi.

BE11:24am

TUI has released updated underlying EBITA guidance for the impact of 737 Max
aircraft grounding. The company guides to €200m one-off impact (-17% FY19E) on
the assumption that 737 Max flights resume by mid-July 2019. Should contingency
measures need to be extended to the end of September, TUI guides to a total
impact of €300m (-26% FY19E). Management attribute this impact to costs of
replacement aircraft, higher fuel costs, other disruption costs and the anticipated
impact on trading. Contingency measures include; utilizing spare fleet aircraft,
extending expiring leases for aircraft due to be replaced by 737 Max and leasing
new aircraft. We expect TUI to be able to reclaim some of the costs associated with
leasing new aircraft from the manufacturer.
 Although one off in nature this guidance is higher than we had anticipated. Press
reports had pointed to a cost in the region of c€3m per week for leasing in
alternative aircraft which would have implied a cost to mid-July of closer to €50m.
TUI’s appraisal is clearly more wide-ranging than this and includes other disruption
costs and the anticipated impact on trading. The bears may feel that there is an
element of padding in this number given the ongoing tough trading environment and
Brexit uncertainty in particular and the share price weakness today (-9%) suggests
that the market regards roughly half of the €200m cost as one off. While this may
seem like a harsh assessment we struggle to see investor sentiment improving on
the stock until there is more clarity on peak summer trading.

BE11:25am

Guidance change will take TUI close to 3x leverage target ceiling this year. Importantly, this is not a covenant, merely an internal target (which can be flexed for one-off issues). We would expect the majority of the costs to be cash, meaning a €200-300m increase in net debt alongside the fall in EBITA. TUI's dividend policy is unchanged (this would need to be stated in the release if not the case), which is for the dividend to grow in-line with underlying EBITA, so the dividend will not be scrapped but there is no commitment to a stable/progressive dividend, meaning it will be cut by 17-26% vs 2018 in-line with the fall in profit.

BE11:42am

AZN last night announced a bold and surprising move to raise capital via a placing to fund the licensing of copromotion rights to an asset we have long had on our radar: Daiichi’s innovative HER2 ADC trastuzumab deruxtecan/DS8201. The latter initially represented a potentially indirect competitive risk for Roche’s HER2 franchise with a focus on extending therapy into low HER2 expressors (initially in breast but then potentially more broadly – we remind Herceptin is approved in Gastric), though recently 8201 became more of a direct threat with the initiation of a direct H2H study vs Kadcyla in 2L mBC. First filing is due H219 in salvage HER2+ mBC, with trials in earlier lines of therapy and HER2+ NSCLC, gastric and CRC ongoing.

· Whilst TD data has been impressive we do note toxicity is not totally benign (e.g. the signal of pulmonary toxicity which came up in our recent discussion with Roche R&D management: Conference feedback: Roche (ROG) (14/03/19)) and HER2 competition is not benign – with Roche investing behind its own early HER2 portfolio (see the same note…). We note that 2024E Evaluate consensus estimates for TD are currently $1.4bn in breast cancer only, with nothing for other indications.

[W]e take some comfort from the fact that the current CEO has plenty of HER2 experience and the incoming oncology head Jose Baselga is a HER2 guru and has likely had a lot of input into the deal. We suspect the market will take the deal positively once it gets over any surprise on the placing aspect.

BE11:43am

And JP Morgan.

BE11:43am

Overall, we see the Daiichi asset as having significant potential, and though the returns may be back-end
weighted, based on the early stage of development (outside 3rd-line HER2+ve mBC), we see this collaboration
as a significant positive, driving accretion from 2020 onward.
However, we are more mixed on the equity raise, firstly because the fact that Astra are raising more than they
need for the Daiichi deal speaks to the strain that the company’s balance sheet is already under, and the fact that
this strain isn’t going to be resolved organically. Secondly, because although the potential for an equity funded
deal had been discussed at some length over the last year (including a question recently asked on the Q3’18
call), we believe investors had got more comfortable that such a deal wasn’t going to take place. We expect
some questions this morning as to why Astra are choosing to do the deal now (shares very close to all time
high), just ahead of the roxadustat MACE safety readout, rather than raising post this imminent data readout.

The deal structure partly mitigates the financial risk, in our view, but $1.35bn upfront plus significant future milestones likely necessitates blockbuster peak sales to deliver a return, albeit exclusivity is expected into 2030s.

BE12:04pm

James Grzinic at Jefferies says ........

BE12:04pm

H&M's 50% Q1 EBIT beat is the first +ve profit surprise in many quarters. The stock's
outsized short position is driving today's technical rebound. But we are reluctant
to get too excited on fundamentals at these levels, despite supportive premises to
Q2 earnings, as we reflect: 1) a full valuation pre-update given family purchases;
2) ongoing EBIT margin declines; 3) a more normalised base of comparison in the
months ahead.
Small Numbers, Big Percentages
H&M reported Q1 sales/EBITDA/EBIT growth inc fx of +10.5%+5.6%-17% YoY, with
the latter coming in at SEK1.005bn (JEFe/cons SEK617m/SEK679m). The resulting
-65bps YoY fall in EBIT margin materialised despite +15bps in gross margin. This
in turn was the result of a number of conflicting factors: markdown reductions
helping by +150bps; new IT/logistics platform exceptional costs at -50bps; and the
balancing -85bps made up of ongoing value reinvestment and fx input headwinds.
Cost growth continues to remain elevated at +11.7% (5.5% ex fx, admittedly c.140bps
lower than we had feared). Ongoing online shift (Q1 sales here +18%, implying c.+8%
at stores inc fx) likely remains the biggest driver, reflecting the increasing popularity
of free deliveries/returns enjoyed by H&M Club members (with membership up to
35m from c.30m in Nov 2018). The over-stocked position worsened (trailing 12M
inventories at 18.6% of sales, vs 17.9% in Q4), but H&M notes this was due to new
season items. Net debt increased by SEK7bn YoY to SEK8.7bn.
And A Supportive Q2 Backdrop
H&M has set out a fairly upbeat backdrop for its next quarterly print. Organic sales
have grown by 7% in March (was 4% in Q1), suggesting LFL in excess of c.4%
And markdown reductions will also be a feature. The completion of work on the
revamped German online offering should translate into stepped up sales in that
market (German sales fell 7% ex fx in Q1, and group online sales gains would have
been 34% once the German hiatus is excluded). But we also remain alert to the
changing base of comparison, which will look much more normal in H2 (when H&M
will cycle a 3% gross profit increase ex fx, vs a -3% in H1). In addition, fx dynamics
remain unhelpful for COGS. And we expect March 2018 to have offered a particularly
easy comp (with LFL sales likely high single digit -ve).
But Family Buying Means Valuation Already There
We welcome H&M's suggestion that the free delivery/returns proposition for club
members will be reviewed and likely optimised. This offering makes judging the
drivers to the sales improvements pretty challenging. But the shares are likely
rerating a little today from their pre update 19x 2019 P/E. Indeed the Q1 underlying
dynamics suggest no obvious gross margin support should be expected once the
markdown tailwind ebbs away later this year (and as a result FY estimates are
unlikely to shift materially). With this in mind we remain on the sidelines.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

And CVS, as per request.

CVS Group PLC (CVSG:LSE): Last: 615.50, up 98.5 (+19.05%), High: 621.00, Low: 542.50, Volume: 1.11m
BE12:05pm

The trading update with the interims reads better than expected, with a pick-up in LFL sales, improvement in gross margin and reduction in vacancy rate. This does not remove the issues, but certainly eases any concerns regarding short term issues and the balance sheet. LFL sales in practices +3.2% in H1, with Jan/Feb +c5% helped by price increases and milder weather. We are nudging up our PBT forecast by 3%-5% to reflect the recent improvements. The shares continue to look exceptional value on 8x EV/Ebitda to June 2020E given that recent industry acquisitions for similar businesses are closer to 15x. CVS is an obvious target for the industry consolidators. Shares trading on a PE of 10.7x and 8.1x EV/Ebitda to Jun 2020E.
